title: Chip Maker Xilinx Searches for New CFO to Help Lead Expansion
text:
A Xilinx sign displayed at an expo in Shanghai. The company’s shares fell 6.8% Friday.

Chip maker Xilinx Inc. is looking for a new finance chief to help lead its expansion into new markets and boost revenue for its data-center and automotive businesses, the company said.

The San Jose, Calif.-based company Thursday said Lorenzo Flores plans to leave after the company reports fiscal second-quarter results Oct. 23. He will join a rival, Toshiba Memory Holdings Corp., as vice chairman in November, the Japanese chip maker said.

Xilinx has begun a formal search for a CFO. “This person should be able to make strategic recommendations to the CEO and provide value beyond the accounting skill set,” a company spokeswoman told The Wall Street Journal.

The new CFO also would lead mergers and acquisitions and expand the company’s operations in the U.S., China and India, the spokeswoman said. Xilinx shares fell 6.8% to $96.55 Friday on the Nasdaq. The company announced the news after regular trading hours Thursday. Mr. Flores worked at Xilinx for 11 years, the past three years as CFO. Sumeet Gagneja, the company’s chief accounting officer, and Matt Poirier, an executive who is taking on the treasurer role at Xilinx, will handle finance operations while the company looks for a new finance chief, Xilinx said. The CFO’s departure could signal some headwinds for the company in the next one or two quarters, said Kinngai Chan, senior research analyst at Summit Insights Group LLC. He added that management’s outlook for fiscal 2020 is too aggressive given the global economic climate. A Bank of America analyst report said the departure was surprising given Xilinx made the announcement 11 days before the quarter’s end. Xilinx attributes the timing to a Securities and Exchange Commission rule that companies report major events within four business days of the occurrence. Mr. Flores submitted his resignation Sept. 17, the company spokeswoman said. The Bank of America report also said rising competition in the 5G market presents a challenge for the company. The investment bank on Friday cut Xilinx to neutral and lowered its price target on the stock to $115 from $150. Toshiba Memory, which will be rebranded as Kioxia Holdings Corp. on Oct. 1, spun off from parent Toshiba Corp. last year. The company is preparing for an initial public offering. —Micah Maidenberg and Patrick Sheridan contributed to this article Write to Mark Maurer at mark.maurer@wsj.com
